samples.context: There is much variation in size, shape and number of cells in different organisms, and also in various parts of the body. Most of the cells are only a few micrometres in diameter and are visible only with the help of a microscope. Cells may be spherical, spindle shaped, elongated, polyhedral or irregular in shape.
samples.question: What determines the shape of cells?

samples.context: Cells were discovered in 1665 by an English Botanist, Robert Hooke. He used a primitive microscope to observe cells in a cork slice.
samples.question: Who discovered cells and when?

samples.context: The number of cells is related to the size of the organ or body. Thus, small organisms have a limited number of cells, while the larger ones such as elephant, whale or banyan tree have a countless number of cells.
samples.question: How does organism size affect cell number?

samples.question: What tool is necessary to see most cells?

samples.question: Can organisms have different types of cells?
